The high mass transfer resistance of reactants and products limits the catalytic process of Silicalite-1 (S-1) based catalysts for volatile organic compounds (VOCs) oxidation. In the present work, Pt/S-1 catalysts with hierarchical pore structure were prepared with different concentrations of organic alkali TPAOH. The Pt/S-1–0.1 catalyst pretreated with 0.1 mol/L tetrapropyl ammonium hydroxide (TPAOH) has excellent VOCs catalytic oxidation activity for various types of VOCs including benzene, n-hexane, toluene, xylene, propane and propylene. The proper concentration of organic alkali pretreatment enhanced the interaction between Pt nanoparticles and the surface of zeolites, thus promoting the dispersion and anchoring of Pt on the surface of zeolites. The high dispersion of Pt nanoparticles with high proportion of Pt0 species benefits the catalytic oxidation of VOCs at low temperature. In addition, due to the hydrophobic nature of S-1 zeolite, Pt/S-1–0.1 catalyst shows strong water resistance and excellent stability, which is suitable for catalytic oxidation of VOCs under high-water vapor content. Graphical Abstract Keywords VOCs oxidation Pt/S-1 catalyst Hierarchical porous structure Pt dispersion Water resistance Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are the main air pollutants in industrial waste gas, seriously harming humans and the natural environment[1]. Among the current treatment methods for VOCs, catalytic combustion is recognized as the most effective method because of its high efficiency and low cost[2]. The research and development of high-performance catalysts is the key to the application of catalytic oxidative degradation technology. Supported noble metal catalysts have the advantages of low oxidation temperature, low energy consumption and less secondary pollutants, and are ideal catalysts for VOCs oxidation[3–10]. However, besides the scarcity and high price of precious metal resources, the water vapor contained in the reaction atmosphere often leads to the decrease of the activity of precious metal catalysts in the actual working conditions[11]. Therefore, it is of great significance to develop catalysts with reduced precious metals and strong water resistance. Silicalite-1 (S-1) zeolite is an all-silicon MFI zeolite without aluminum and titanium, which has a large specific surface area, special pore structure, good thermal stability and excellent hydrophobic performance. As a support material, the hydrophobic nature of S-1 zeolite is favorable to improve the water resistance of the catalyst[12,13]. For example, Wang et. al adopt a facile method to prepare Silicalite-1@Ag (S-1@Ag) mixed matrix membranes (MMM) by in-situ embedding the Ag+ into the pores of the hydrophobic S-1 zeolite, in which the hydrophobicity nature and framework shielding towards Ag+ of S-1 guarantees the excellent almost 2-months stable separation of C2H4/C2H6 under the high relative humidity conditions[12]. Chen et. al enveloped Cu/ZSM-5 core by S-1 shell with confined Ag0 nanoparticles, which present superior hydrothermal stability and highly selective low-temperature ammonia oxidation, due to the fact that the hydrophobic silicalite-1 shell effectively reinforces the hydrothermal stability of the core-shell Cu/ZSM-5@Ag/S-1[13]. However, S-1 is a microporous zeolite with a small and single pore size, which leads to high mass transfer resistance of reactants and products in the process of catalytic reaction[14], and is not conducive to the dispersion of precious metals on the surface of zeolites. It is easy to cause the agglomeration of precious metal particles. The introduction of hierarchical pore structure by acid or alkali treatment can effectively reduce the steric hindrance and increase the mass transfer rate. At the same time, it can also improve the interaction of Pt-carriers and improve the stability of precious metals[15]. But inorganic acid (HCl) or alkali (NaOH) and other reagents are easy to over-etch the framework structure of zeolites, resulting in the collapse of the zeolites structure[16]. Therefore, developing suitable methods and conditions to introduce hierarchical pore structure has become a new research direction. In the present work, different concentrations of organic base TPAOH were introduced to S-1 zeolite to create hierarchical pore structure, and a series of Pt/S-1 catalysts (Pt loading 0.5 wt%) were prepared by liquid phase reduction of ethylene glycol. The catalytic oxidation activity of these catalysts for different kinds of VOCs and the stability of the catalysts in the atmosphere containing H2O and CO2 were investigated. By means of the characterization methods of X-ray diffraction (XRD), nitrogen isothermal adsorption-desorption (N2-adsorption/desorption isotherms), high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), in-situ CO adsorption infrared (CO In-situ FTIR), H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and VOCs temperature-programmed surface reaction (VOCs-TPSR), the texture-structure properties, morphology and redox ability of the catalysts were investigated and the structure-activity relationship between the structure of the catalyst and the catalytic oxidation activity was also deeply discussed. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials NaOH, Tetrapropyl ammonium hydroxide (TPAOH), H2PtCl6, and ethylene glycol were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co, Ltd. Anhydrous ethanol was purchased from Hangzhou Longshan Fine Chemical Co, Ltd. S-1 zeolite was purchased from Catalyst Plant of Nankai University. Pure N2 was purchased from Hangzhou Jingong Special Gas Co., Ltd. 2.2 Synthesis of catalysts 3 g S-1 zeolite was added to 50 mL TPAOH organic alkali solution with different concentrations (0.05 mol L−1, 0.1 mol L−1, 0.2 mol L−1 and 0.4 mol L−1) and stirred continuously for 8 h in a 60 ℃ water bath. After stirring, the precipitate is separated by centrifugation and washed with deionized water many times until the supernatant is neutral. Then, 1.5 mL H2PtCl6 aqueous solution (1 g Pt/100 mL) was added to 50 mL ethylene glycol solution, stirring while adding 3 g alkali-treated S-1 zeolite, stirring at room temperature for 3 h, and then refluxing in a 160 ℃ oil bath under N2 protection for 6 h. At the end of the reaction, the precipitate was cooled to room temperature, the precipitate was separated by centrifugation, and washed with ethanol many times until the supernatant was neutral. The product was dried at 100 ℃ for 12 h and roasted at 500 ℃ for 2 h. The prepared Pt/S-1 catalysts were named Pt/S-1–0.05, Pt/S-1–0.1, Pt/S-1–0.2and Pt/S-1–0.4 respectively. In addition, Pt/S-1 catalyst without organic alkali pretreatment was prepared, which was named Pt/S-1–0. The actual Pt contents of the catalysts determined by ICP-OES were 0.45 wt%, 0.45 wt%, 0.48 wt%, 0.48 wt%, and 0.47 wt% respectively for Pt/S-1–0, Pt/S-1–0.05, Pt/S-1–0.1, Pt/S-1–0.2 and Pt/S-1–0.4, which are very close to the theoretical Pt content of 0.5 wt%. The specific details of the characterization methods and performance evaluation methods are presented in the supplementary material. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural and texture properties of Pt/S-1catalysts In order to study the effect of organic alkali pretreatment on the framework structure of zeolites, a series of Pt/S-1 catalysts were characterized by XRD and the XRD patterns are shown in Fig. 1. After organic alkali treatment, the catalyst still retains the MFI-type structural characteristic diffraction peak[17]. However, with the increase of organic alkali treatment concentration, the crystallinity of the catalyst decreases gradually, and when the organic alkali treatment concentration reaches 0.4 mol L−1, the crystallinity of the catalyst is only 84 % of that of the Pt/S-1–0 catalyst without organic alkali treatment, indicating that excessively high concentration of organic alkali treatment may over-etch the zeolite framework structure, resulting in the destruction of part of the zeolite structure. In addition, the characteristic diffraction peaks of Pt species (2θ = 39.8°, 46.2°) were not found in the XRD spectra of all Pt/S-1 series catalysts[18,19]. This is due to the low Pt loading, small particle size and high dispersion of Pt species on the surface of Pt/S-1 zeolite. Fig. 1(b) shows the pore size distribution of Pt/S-1 series catalysts, and the corresponding specific surface area, pore volume and average pore size are listed in Table 1. It can be seen from Fig. 1(b) that the Pt/S-1–0 catalyst without organic alkali treatment is mainly micropore structure, while the Pt/S-1–0.1 and Pt/S-1–0.4 catalysts treated with organic alkali show micropore-mesoporous structure, which indicates that TPAOH organic alkali pretreatment successfully introduces mesoporous structure into zeolites. However, when the concentration of organic alkali is too high, the mesoporous distribution above 4 nm may be obviously increased due to over etching. The micropore volume of the catalyst decreases and the mesopore volume increases with the increase of organic alkali treatment concentration, indicating that the mesoporous structure introduced by TPAOH organic alkali pretreatment is formed on the basis of the original micropore structure. Combined with the previous literature[20–22], the process of introducing mesoporous structure into TPAOH organic alkali treatment were summarized as following: in the process of TPAOH alkali treatment, OH- anions in TPAOH solution mainly dissolve part of silicon species in the zeolite framework, resulting in the formation of mesoporous structure on the basis of micropore structure. Therefore, with the increase of the concentration of TPAOH solution, the number of OH- anions increased, resulting in the increase of mesoporous volume and the decrease of micropore volume of the catalyst. And in TPAOH solution, TPA+ cations can be combined with the surface of zeolites to stabilize the structure of zeolites and prevent the framework structure of zeolites from being destroyed excessively, because TPA+ cations are the structure-oriented agents in the synthesis of S-1 zeolite. In addition, it can be seen from Table 1 that after 0.1 M organic alkali treatment, the specific surface area of the catalyst increases obviously, which may be beneficial to the adsorption and activation of reaction molecules on the catalyst surface. After 0.4 M organic alkali treatment, the specific surface area of the catalyst decreased obviously, which was related to its over etching. In order to observe the effect of organic alkali treatment on the surface structure of zeolite and the dispersion of Pt nanoparticles, the morphology of the catalyst was observed by HRTEM. Fig. 1 shows the HRTEM images and the statistical diagram of particle size distribution of Pt nanoparticles of the series Pt/S-1 catalysts. It can be seen from the figure that the pretreatment of organic alkali leaves obvious etching marks on the surface of zeolite and roughens the originally flat surface of S-1 zeolite. With the increase of the concentration of organic alkali treatment, the etching marks on the surface of the catalyst are gradually obvious, and the most obvious etching trace could be observed in the Pt/S-1–0.4. The Pt/S-1–0.4 catalyst shows some transparent pores, which is consistent with the conclusion that high concentration of organic alkali pretreatment leads to over etching of the zeolite framework and a decrease in crystallinity in the XRD results. The particle size and dispersion of Pt nanoparticles can also be observed in HRTEM images. The order of average particle size of Pt/S-1 series catalysts is as follows: Pt/S-1–0.1(4.8 nm) < Pt/S-1–0.2 (5.5 nm) < Pt/S-1–0.4 (6.3 nm) < Pt/S-1–0 (10.4 nm). As platinum (Pt) is loaded onto the etched S-1 zeolite, the increased Si-OH groups on the etched S-1 surface can bond with Pt precursors (e.g., H₂PtCl₆) through Si-O-Pt-Clₓ linkages, forming more stable anchoring sites that suppress metal migration and sintering[23]. The mesoporous edges and surface defects created by TPAOH etching act as nucleation sites for Pt nanoparticles, promoting highly dispersed of Pt nanoparticles (e.g., the average Pt particle size decreases from 10.4 nm in Pt/S-1–0–4.8 nm in Pt/S-1–0.1). But in the Pt/S-1–0.4 catalyst treated with high concentration organic alkali, the agglomeration of Pt particles on the surface of zeolite was more serious and its average particle size became larger. In order to further study the dispersion of Pt nanoparticles on the catalysts, CO In-situ DRIFTs experiments were carried out and the spectra of Pt/S-1 catalysts were shown in Fig. 1(c). In the range of 2000–2100 cm−1, the Pt/S-1 catalyst has only one CO adsorption peak at 2080–2100 cm−1, which belongs to the linear adsorption of CO[24]. Because the edges and corners of small Pt particles are easy to adsorb more CO, the area of the CO adsorption peak is usually regarded as an index to compare the particle size and dispersion of precious metal nanoparticles on catalysts. The order of CO adsorption peak area on Pt/S-1 catalysts is as follows: Pt/S-1–0.1 > Pt/S-1–0.2 > Pt/S1–0.3 > Pt/S-1–0.4 > Pt/S-1–0.05 > Pt/S-1–0, which is consistent with the order of particle size of Pt nanoparticles observed under HRTEM, indicating that the appropriate concentration of organic alkali pretreatment can promote the dispersion of Pt on the surface of zeolites, which is beneficial to the production of small size Pt nanoparticles. In addition, it can be observed from the spectrum that after organic alkali treatment, the CO adsorption peak on Pt/S-1 series catalysts first red-shifted and then blue-shifted. This is because the appropriate concentration of organic alkali treatment (0.1 mol L−1) is beneficial to the dispersion of Pt nanoparticles on Pt/S-1–0.1 catalyst, and enhances the interaction between S-l zeolite and Pt nanoparticles, thus increasing the ability of Pt to provide electrons to the π* unoccupied empty orbitals of CO molecules, resulting in a red shift of the CO adsorption band[25]. However, when the concentration of organic alkali treatment further increased, part of the framework structure of the zeolite was destroyed, which led to the agglomeration of Pt nanoparticles, the weakening of the interaction with the carrier, and the blue shift of the CO adsorption band. 3.2 Catalytic performance of Pt/S-1 catalysts for VOCs catalytic oxidation The catalytic oxidation activity of Pt/S-1 series catalysts pretreated with different concentrations of TPAOH for benzene and n-hexane is shown in Fig. 2(a) and (b) respectively. The catalytic oxidation activity of each catalyst for benzene is compared by T90 % value (temperature when the conversion of reactants reaches 90 %). It was found that the catalytic activity of the catalyst for the oxidation of benzene and n-hexane was significantly improved after organic alkali treatment. When the concentration of organic base increased to 0.1 mol L−1, the catalytic oxidation activity of benzene and n-hexane increased gradually, and Pt/S-1–0.1 catalyst shows the best catalytic oxidation activity. The T90 % of benzene and n-hexane catalytic oxidation was only 129 ℃ and 149 ℃, while that of benzene and n-hexane on Pt/S-1–0 catalyst without organic alkali treatment was 184 ℃ and 200 ℃, respectively. However, when the concentration of organic base further increased, the catalytic oxidation activity of Pt/S-1 catalysts for n-hexane decreased to a certain extent. According to their T90 % values for benzene and n-hexane catalytic oxidation, the order of benzene oxidation activity of this series of catalysts was as follows: Pt/S-1–0.1 > Pt/S-1–0.05 ≈ Pt/S-1–0.2 ≈ Pt/S-1–0.4 > Pt/S-1–0, and the order of oxidation activity for n-hexane is as follows: Pt/S-1–0.1 > Pt/S-1–0.2 > Pt/S-1–0.4 ≈Pt/S-1–0.05 > Pt/S-1–0, may be due to the different effects of different concentrations of organic alkali pretreatment on the structure of zeolites, resulting in differences in the dispersion state of Pt species and the interaction between Pt species and S-1 support. Moreover, we compared the catalytic activity of the present work to that of some representative noble metal supported catalysts reported in the reference, as listed in Table S1 [26–31]. It is obvious that Pt/S-1–0.1 catalyst in the present work shows superior catalytic activity among these catalysts comprehensively considering the temperature required for complete oxidation of benzene as well as the specific reaction rate at 120 °C and TOF values. The catalytic performance for the oxidation of benzene, toluene, xylene, n-hexane, propane, and propylene was evaluated on Pt/S-1–0.1 catalyst with the best catalytic oxidation activity and Pt/S-1–0 catalyst without organic alkali treatment. As shown in Fig. 3 and Table 2, compared with Pt/S-1–0 catalyst, Pt/S-1–0.1 catalyst also shows higher catalytic oxidation activity for toluene, xylene, propylene and propane, with T90 % values of 145 ℃, 169 ℃, 115 ℃ and 243 ℃, respectively. It indicates that Pt/S-1–0.1catalyst has excellent adaptability for the oxidation of different types of VOCs. It is noticed that the T90 % of propane is significantly higher than that of other VOCs, which is mainly due to that propane is a saturated alkane (C-C single bonds) with extremely low molecular polarity and its oxidation relies directly on gas-phase oxygen activation, requiring highly reactive oxygen species (e.g., O⁻ or O₂⁻), which form only at elevated temperatures[19,32]. In addition, the T90 % of Pt/S-1–0.1 catalyst for propane oxidation is much lower than the literatures (Table S2)[33,34], indicating the high activity of Pt/S-1–0.1 catalyst. 3.3 Water resistance and stability of Pt/S-1 catalyst Because in the actual industrial conditions, VOCs is usually discharged with water vapor, which is easily adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst and results in the decrease of catalytic oxidation activity of the catalyst[11,35,36]. Therefore, the water resistance of the catalyst is an important index of whether the catalyst can achieve industrial application. Therefore, the effect of water vapor content on the activity of Pt/S-1–0.1 catalyst was also investigated. As shown in Fig. 4, with the introduction of 3 vol% of water vapor, the catalytic oxidation activity of the catalyst for benzene and n-hexane decreased to a certain extent, with the T90 % value increasing about 15 ℃, but compared with Pt/S-1–0 catalyst, it still maintained high activity for benzene and n-hexane oxidation. Moreover, with the further increase of water vapor content (10 vol%), the catalytic oxidation activity of the catalyst for benzene and n-hexane remained almost unchanged, indicating that Pt/S-1–0.1catalyst has strong water resistance and is suitable for low temperature catalytic oxidation of VOCs under the condition of high water vapor content. The strong water resistance is attributed to the strong hydrophobicity of the pure siliceous S-1 zeolite, which inhibits the adsorption of water molecules on the S-1 support and alleviates the competitive adsorption of water and VOCs on the catalyst surface, thus improving the water resistance of the catalyst [37]. The stability of the catalyst is also an important index in the practical industrial application of the catalyst. The stability of Pt/S-1–0.1 and Pt/S-1–0 catalysts were also evaluated under the condition of benzene concentration of 1000 ppm and space velocity of 32500 h−1. In the atmosphere of actual industrial conditions, the emission of VOCs is usually accompanied by H2O, CO2 and other gases. Therefore, the stability of the catalysts under actual industrial conditions was also performed with the introduction of 5 vol% H2O for 10 h, 5 vol% CO2 for 5 h and 5 vol% H2O+ 5 vol% CO2 for 6 h in the reaction process. As shown in Fig. 5(a), although the reaction temperature was lower (130 ℃), the catalytic activity of Pt/S1–0.1 catalyst for benzene oxidation did not decrease under all atmosphere conditions, and the conversion was always maintained at about 90 %. Compared with Pt/S-1–0 catalyst in Fig. 5(b), Pt/S-1–0 catalyst decreased obviously with the introduction of 5 vol% H2O+ 5 vol% CO2 to the reaction gas, and its activity did not recover completely after switching off H2O vapor and CO2. This result shows that Pt/S-1–0.1 catalyst has excellent stability and good anti-H2O and anti-CO2 interference activity. The primary reasons include the following two aspects. Firstly, compared to the unetched Pt/S-1–0 catalyst, the TPAOH-etched Pt/S1–0.1 catalyst forms a hierarchical mesoporous-microporous structure, which increases the specific surface area and pore volume of the catalyst. This facilitates the adsorption and activation of reactant molecules on the catalyst surface. The larger specific surface area also promotes the high dispersion of Pt species and the formation of smaller Pt nanoparticles, enhancing the interaction between Pt and the S-1 zeolite. This interaction helps anchor Pt nanoparticles, suppress carbon deposition and sintering during the catalytic oxidation of benzene, and demonstrates improved stability. Secondly, as mentioned in the introduction, S-1 zeolite within the MFI framework is an all-silica molecular sieve without the introduction of aluminum or titanium sites, endowing it with unique thermal stability and hydrophobicity. Consequently, S-1-supported materials exhibit superior gas separation capabilities and hydrothermal catalytic stability under high humidity conditions. Furthermore, to characterize the effect of TPAOH etching on the hydrophobicity of S-1 zeolite, we measured the water contact angles of Pt/S-1–0.1 and Pt/S-1–0 catalysts. As shown in Fig. S1, the water contact angle increased from 7.5°to 19.5° respectively for Pt/S-1–0 and Pt/S-1–0.1, indicating enhanced hydrophobicity caused by the TPAOH etching. This improvement enables the Pt/S-1–0.1 catalyst to demonstrate superior water resistance compared to Pt/S-1–0. 3.4 XPS spectra and H2-TPR profiles of Pt/S-1 catalyst Fig. 6(a) shows the Pt 4 f XPS spectra of Pt/S-1 series catalysts, in which the Pt4f5/2 peak at 70.8 eV and the Pt4f7/2 peak at 74.1 eV belong to the Pt0 species, and the Pt4f5/2 peak at 72.2 eV and the Pt4f7/2 peak at 75.5 eV belong to the Pt2+ species. Table 3 lists the valence distribution of Pt species. The Pt species in Pt/S-1 catalysts mainly exist in the form of Pt0, and the Pt0 content increases at first and then decreases with the increase of organic alkali treatment concentration. According to the literatures [38], the Pt0 species is the active center for the catalytic oxidation of benzene and n-hexane. The order of Pt0 content in the Pt/S-1 series of catalysts is: Pt/S-1–0.1 higher than Pt/S-1–0.2 higher than Pt/S-1–0.4 higher than Pt/S-1–0, which is consistent with the evaluation results of catalytic oxidation activity. The higher Pt0 content represents the stronger interaction between Pt-zeolite supports. Specifically, the electrons on the oxygen in the zeolite frame would transfer to the Pt atom, and the net charge on the Pt atom is zero so that the Pt species exists in the form of Pt0 [39–41]. Simultaneously, the enriched Si-OH groups may modulate the electron density of Pt via hydrogen bonding or weak coordination effects. XPS analysis reveals a slight positive shift in the Pt 4 f binding energy (∼0.2–0.5 eV), indicating partial electron transfer from Pt to the support. This electron-deficient state enhances the oxidative capability of Pt. In addition, the surface Pt content of each catalyst measured by XPS was significantly higher than its Pt loading, indicating that the Pt species were mainly dispersed on the surface of zeolites. It is obvious that the Pt content on the catalyst surface increased further after organic alkali treatment. This confirms that the proper concentration of organic alkali treatment would roughen the surface of zeolite, which is beneficial to the dispersion and anchoring of Pt nanoparticles on the outer surface of zeolite, and promote the catalytic oxidation of VOCs by the catalyst. However, too high a concentration of organic alkali will lead to excessive etching on the surface of zeolites, induce the agglomeration of some Pt nanoparticles or trapped in pores, which is not conducive to the catalytic oxidation of VOCs. Therefore, good Pt dispersion and high Pt0 content are important reasons for the high activity of Pt/S-1–0.1 catalysts for VOCs. The redox property of the catalyst has a great influence on the catalytic oxidation of VOCs. The redox ability of Pt species in the Pt/S-1 series of catalysts was characterized by H2-TPR experiments, and the results are shown in Fig. 6(b).There are two reduction peaks in this series of catalysts, in which the lower temperature α peak belongs to the reduction peak of PtOx species, and the β peak at high temperature belongs to the Pt species reduction peak of Pt-(O-Si) n − y y , which combines with Si-O bond to form complexes. The strong interaction species between Pt and S-1 zeolite are more stable and need a higher reduction temperature. As shown in Fig. 6(b), when the organic alkali treatment concentration is less than 0.1 mol L−1, the reduction temperature of α peak and β peak decreases gradually with the increase of organic alkali treatment concentration. This indicates that the proper concentration of organic alkali pretreatment promotes the dispersion of Pt nanoparticles on the surface of zeolites, facilitates the formation of small Pt particles, and improves the low temperature reduction performance of the catalyst. However, when the concentration of organic alkali higher than 0.1 mol L−1, the reduction temperature of α peak and β peak gradually increases with the increase of organic alkali treatment concentration, due to the particle size of Pt nanoparticles formed by the excessive concentration of organic alkali pretreatment that over-etched the surface of zeolite. The order of low temperature reduction performance of Pt/S-1 series catalysts is consistent with that of benzene and n-hexane, indicating that the better low temperature reduction performance of catalysts is beneficial to the low temperature catalytic oxidation of alkanes and aromatic hydrocarbons. From Fig. S2, it can be seen that the five catalysts show only one NH3 desorption peak between 50 and 150 ℃ that attribute to the NH3 adsorbed on the weak acid site[42]. There is no NH3 desorption peak at higher temperature, due to that the S-1 zeolite does not contain aluminum (Al) and lacks traditional Brønsted acid sites (Al-OH-Si). The limited acidity of the Pt/S-1 catalyst may be due to the surface silanol groups (Si-OH), which weakly adsorb NH₃ through hydrogen bonds or weak proton acid properties. Moreover, the acidity of the Pt/S-1 zeolite shows no significant change as the concentration of TPAOH is low. However, the NH₃ desorption peak area on the catalyst surface decreases markedly as the TPAOH concentration exceeds 0.2 mol/L, indicating that excessive TPAOH etching destroys the weak acidic sites on the catalyst surface and leads to a significant reduction in acidity. Nevertheless, the weak acidic sites on the S-1 zeolite surface exhibit only limited adsorption capacity for benzene. Therefore, the variation in surface acidity is not a critical factor affecting the catalytic performance of Pt/S-1 for the catalytic oxidation of benzene. 3.5 TPSR of Pt/S-1 catalyst In the catalytic oxidation of VOCs, VOCs are usually adsorbed on the catalyst before catalytic oxidation, so the adsorption performance of the catalyst to VOCs will affect its catalytic oxidation performance. In order to study the VOCs adsorption and desorption ability of the catalyst and the deep oxidation capacity of the catalyst, Benzene-TPSR experiments were carried out, and Fig. 7(a) shows the adsorption curve of benzene on the catalyst. It can be seen that the time required for the catalyst to reach benzene adsorption equilibrium becomes longer after organic alkali treatment, indicating that the adsorption capacity of the catalyst increases. And the specific order is as follows: Pt/S-1–0.1 > Pt/S-1–0.05 ≈ Pt/S-1–0.4 ≈ Pt/S-1–0 ≈ Pt/S-1–0. With the increase of the concentration of organic alkali treatment, the time required for the catalyst to reach the adsorption equilibrium of benzene increases at first and then decreases, which is ascribed to the increased specific surface area and enhanced adsorption capacity of the catalyst for benzene under the appropriate concentration of organic alkali pretreatment condition. However, when the concentration of alkali treatment is too high, part of the framework structure of the catalyst is destroyed, which is not conducive to the adsorption of benzene. Fig. 7(b)-(d) shows the desorption curves of benzene, CO2 and CO during the temperature programmed surface reaction of the catalyst. As shown in Fig. 7(b)-(d), the oxidation process occurs during the desorption of benzene and results in CO2. For Pt/S-1–0 catalyst without organic alkali treatment, the desorption temperature of benzene is about 110 ℃, while the temperature of complete desorption is about 220 ℃, and the maximum peak temperature of CO2 is about 175 ℃. For the Pt/S-1–0.1 catalyst, benzene began to desorb at about 60 ℃, and the temperature of complete desorption and the maximum peak temperature of CO2 also decreased significantly, indicating that the mesoporous pore structure produced by organic alkali pretreatment can reduce the mass transfer resistance of benzene in the reaction process, which is beneficial to the contact between benzene and oxidation active center, therefore improves the catalytic oxidation activity of Pt/S-1–0.1catalyst. In addition, in order to more comprehensively understand the mineralization degree of benzene during the oxidation process, we measured the mineralization rates of Pt/S-1–0.1 catalyst at different temperatures. As shown in Fig. S3, the Pt/S-1–0.1 catalyst reaches 100 % mineralization rates at 150 °C. which is basically consistent with the variation tendency of the desorption curves of CO2 in Fig. 7(c). The boosted intensity of CO2 signals and the 100 % mineralization rates at 150 °C indicate that benzene was totally deep oxidized into CO2 over Pt/S-1–0.1 at 150 °C. At the same time, the production of CO was not detected in the process of benzene desorption and catalytic oxidation on Pt/S-1 series catalysts (Fig. 7(d)), indicating that the catalyst has strong deep oxidation ability, and benzene can be quickly and completely oxidized in the process of catalytic oxidation of benzene. 3.6 Structure-performance relationship discussion According to the literatures[31,43], the reaction pathway for the catalytic oxidation of benzene over Pt/S-1 catalyst follows as: Benzene (C₆H₆) → Partial oxidation intermediates (e.g., phenol, benzoquinone, maleate, acetate) → CO₂ + H₂O (complete oxidation). The specific mechanistic steps including that firstly, benzene adsorbs onto the surface of Pt nanoparticles via π-bond interaction with metallic Pt⁰ sites. Pt nanoparticles dissociate molecular oxygen (O₂) into reactive oxygen species (O⁻, O₂⁻, or O*) at their surfaces. Pt⁰ sites weaken the aromatic C-C bonds of benzene, while activated oxygen species attack C-H bonds, forming hydroxyl (·OH) or peroxide (·OOH) radicals. The aromatic ring is opened via oxidative cleavage, forming linear intermediates (e.g., maleic anhydride or carboxylic acids). These intermediates are fully oxidized to CO₂ and H₂O via sequential C-H and C-C bond breaking[31,43]. The metallic Pt (Pt⁰) nanoparticles dispersed on the zeolite surface act as the main active sites for oxidation reactions. These nanoparticles facilitate the activation of oxygen (O₂) and the dissociation of hydrocarbons (e.g., benzene or n-hexane) via adsorption on their surfaces. Moreover, smaller Pt nanoparticles exhibit higher catalytic activity due to their larger surface-to-volume ratio and greater accessibility for reactant molecules. In Pt/S-1–0.1 catalyst, on one hand, the hierarchical pore structure of the S-1 zeolite helps stabilize Pt nanoparticles, preventing agglomeration and maintaining their high dispersion, which contributes to the excellent catalytic performance of Pt/S-1–0.1 for the catalytic oxidation of benzene. On the other hand, the hydrophobicity of S-1 zeolite prevents water poisoning of Pt active sites and the TPAOH etching further enhances the hydrophobicity of S-1 zeolite, which further promotes the water resistance of Pt/S-1–0.1 catalyst for catalytic oxidation of benzene. 4 Conclusion In the present work, Pt/S-1 catalysts with hierarchical pore structure were prepared with different concentrations of organic alkali TPAOH. The catalytic oxidation activity, water resistance and stability of this series of catalysts for benzene, n-hexane and other alkanes and aromatic hydrocarbons were investigated, and the texture-structure and redox properties of the catalysts were studied by XRD, HRTEM, N2 adsorption/desorption, CO In-situ FTIR, XPS, H2-TPR and TPSR. The results demonstrated that the pretreatment with TPAOH introduces mesoporous structure and form micro-mesoporous structure in S-1 zeolite, which reduces the mass transfer resistance of reactant molecules and is beneficial to the adsorption and desorption of VOCs on the catalyst. The Pt/S-1–0.1 catalyst pretreated with 0.1 mol L−1 TPAOH has excellent VOCs catalytic oxidation activity for different types of VOCs including benzene, n-hexane, toluene, xylene, propane and propylene. The proper concentration of organic alkali pretreatment enhanced the interaction between Pt nanoparticles and the surface of zeolites, thus promoting the dispersion and anchoring of Pt on the surface of zeolites. The small particle size and high dispersion Pt nanoparticles with high proportion of Pt0 species benefit to the catalytic oxidation of VOCs at low temperature. In addition, due to the hydrophobic nature of S-1 zeolite, Pt/S-1–0.1 catalyst shows strong water resistance and excellent stability, which is suitable for low temperature catalytic oxidation of VOCs under the condition of high water vapor content. coredata.dc:description: The high mass transfer resistance of reactants and products limits the catalytic process of Silicalite-1 (S-1) based catalysts for volatile organic compounds (VOCs) oxidation. In the present work, Pt/S-1 catalysts with hierarchical pore structure were prepared with different concentrations of organic alkali TPAOH. The Pt/S-1–0.1 catalyst pretreated with 0.1 mol/L tetrapropyl ammonium hydroxide (TPAOH) has excellent VOCs catalytic oxidation activity for various types of VOCs including benzene, n-hexane, toluene, xylene, propane and propylene. The proper concentration of organic alkali pretreatment enhanced the interaction between Pt nanoparticles and the surface of zeolites, thus promoting the dispersion and anchoring of Pt on the surface of zeolites. The high dispersion of Pt nanoparticles with high proportion of Pt0 species benefits the catalytic oxidation of VOCs at low temperature. In addition, due to the hydrophobic nature of S-1 zeolite, Pt/S-1–0.1 catalyst shows strong water resistance and excellent stability, which is suitable for catalytic oxidation of VOCs under high-water vapor content.

coredata.dc:title: Hierarchical porous S-1 zeolite supported Pt catalyst for catalytic oxidation of various VOCs at low temperature with strong water resistance and excellent stability
